displayed_text: Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: I’m going through your medicines. Still taking your Advair as needed? Patient: Right. Doctor: Your atorvastatin ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Co-Q-ten two hundred a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Lisinopril ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Multivitamin once a day? Patient: No.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Hi, how are you? Doctor: Good. Can I..can I steal that chair? Patient: Sure. Doctor: And that way I can look at you. I can move that one over too. Patient: Can I sit here? Doctor: You can! Patient: Well he put the cameras. Doctor: Oh gee that M___. (laughing) Patient: Oh yeah, that’s right. Doctor: How are you feeling? Happy New Year, by the way. Patient: Thank you. Oh, Hi. How are you?

Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it just might be that we have something that really does look interesting or promising that we can offer you. I don’t want to go into those details today because I don’t know when that time will come or if it will come. But if that time comes, when we’re deciding between a standard therapy, like the two that I mentioned, or a different experimental therapy, I can give you the consent form, and you can think about it, and if you decide to participate that would be through us. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Because I know the discussion we had initially, uh, was the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That was one of the options. And I used the word, chemo bad. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s bad in terms, you know, the side effects are worse than everything you’ve had so far. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but it can be effective against the cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I personally tend to use chemotherapy later than most of the people. Uh, and part of the reason for that is because we have a lot of trials which, you know, we believe in, of course, because they’re our studies. And we have best of interest in them. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we have laboratory research on those things, so we are excited, you know –

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay. Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.

Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug-

Patient: They didn’t tell me anything about it yet. I see Dr. G___ next week. Doctor: And you’re still taking the Enzalutamide? Patient: What’s that? Doctor: The Xtandi. Patient: Yes, I am, yes. Four pills a day. Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. They took blood last time, and ran some protocols and you were going to check on some numbers. Doctor: Anything new on your body that you’ve noticed that you want me to take a look at? Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds)

Patient: though too and this question that - Doctor: remember this is a marathon race. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can’t sprint from thing to thing you’ll be exhausted – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and we won’t go anywhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we’re pacing you. Mm,hmm. Family Member: So, we’ve got four or five more chemos… Doctor: Yeah I think… Family Member: And then we’ll do a scan? Patient: Did you count this as one? Doctor: That was one. So I think we just need to sort of…

Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not. Doctor: You’re right. Chemically, we do it to say this is what's happening Patient: Right. Doctor: - to your testosterone but everyone reacts to the different preparations differently. Patient: The Lupron just knocked me for a loop. They wanted me to be on Lupron for three years, and after a year, I told him I'd rather die. Doctor: Yeah, because it was terrible. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___.

Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh… Doctor: I think you might need surgery to fix that problem. Patient: A surgeon? Doctor: Yeah a urologist. Patient: That sounds like fun. laughs]] Doctor: I know. Laughs]] Well it’s better than constantly dealing with this pestering problem. Family Member: The pestering is what it is.

Patient: Oh, I’m I’m just got the pain medicine going on. Just tired ‘cause I’ve been sitting, I’ve went down there and then I’m sitting out there ‘cause it was you know busy so I’ve been sitting out there for… Doctor: Wow because your appointment was way before I’ve seen so many people so I thought you weren’t here. Patient: No I was over here at the lab. It was so packed over there. Doctor: Oh my gosh you’re kidding me. Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is the pain? (patient makes a noise) Patient: Yeah I took some ah I took my pain medicine… Doctor: Pain medicine. Patient: …before I got here. Doctor: Any better though since we started the chemo? Did you notice any difference in your appetite in your – how you’re feeling? I still feel kind of you know I just had heat flashes and all of that, but the pills that you gave me. Patient: They make me crazy. I was just… Doctor: I think, I think also I started you on the Prednisone remember for your along with the Chemo. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Well I thought maybe you was gonna give me another twenty and ninety. That’s what I was asking. Doctor: Well the Percocet we cannot give more than hundred twenty. Patient: Right. I know, I’m talking about OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah this is a long acting so it’s good for twe- twelve hours. So you only can take it morning and evening. Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight.

Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: By the time there the next day they gave me some potassium and they gave me antibiotics. Doctor: Um hum. Um hum. Yeah. Patient: And was walking in an hour or two. Doctor: Yeah. And you were really dehydrated. Patient: Yeah I was. Doctor: So they had to give you a lot of fluids. So your doctor’s pretty, pretty worried. Your, your lungs, you know, they’re already not great with the cancer but then you had pneumonia on top of that, so. Well, we’ll get those records to make sure that’s, and you know, kind of what ended up happening because they couldn’t give me anything until you were discharged. So now that you’re discharged for a couple of days, they’ll send that up, up to us. Patient: Yeah, Uh the last time they gave me something to take home, antibiotics, some kind of antibiotics to take home, that just I didn’t get nothing. Doctor: Okay. You didn’t get some this time? Okay. So it might have been more flu. Yeah. Okay. So, I’ll, I’ll have M___ come in and say hello and then we’ll have you come back here in a couple of weeks and let’s, let’s run through it. Awesome. Glad you’re back. You scared me. Doctor: You take care of him. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I’ll have her come in and we’ll, we’ll get you out of here. Alright. I’ll see you guys.
